Award.AwardTitle: The Paleoecology and Evolution of White Sharks: An Isotopic Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
Paul Koch
The University of California-Santa Cruz
The Paleoecology and Evolution of White Sharks: An Isotopic Study

This is a study of modern and ancient shark ecology using stable isotope analysis, which permits the quantification of patterns and processes in ecological systems. While isotope systematics have not been studied extensively in sharks, based on the wide utility of isotopic methods in studies of the ecology and paleoecology of other vertebrates, we hope that our approach will broaden our understanding of shark ecology. To lay the foundation for both modern and paleontological research, we will analyze samples from a recently concluded controlled feeding study, which also included calcified structures. The interpretative framework set by our feeding study will allow us to assess the dietary and habitat preferences of modern white sharks off the California coast. We will sub-sample annual growth bands in the vertebrae of white sharks collected from the mid-to-late 20th century. Our study should reveal growth and seasonal shifts within an individual?s lifetime, as well as possible ecological changes associated with the increase in the marine mammal populations since the 1970s.

Our project featuring modern and ancient white sharks will contribute to critical ecological questions, which are difficult to answer with other tools. Our past work have had practical impacts for our understanding of the ecology and conservation biology of modern species. This work has brought a new set of tools to modern ecology and it can offer an essential historical context for the study of modern ecosystems. This project will contribute to the education of UCSC graduate and undergraduate students. It will support the mentoring of a post-doctoral researcher. It will train a Ph.D. student. We expect undergraduate students to develop senior thesis projects around this study. We will explore developing a new course on historical marine ecology, using information from this proposal and prior studies of seals, condors, and other taxa. Our results will also contribute to a new fossil shark website associated with the Florida Natural History Museums Ichthyology Department. These outreach venues will allow educators, youth, and the general public to explore ancient and modern shark ecology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The hard, calcified tissues of sharks include teeth and vertebral centra can preserve chemical information about diet and the environment in which animals live. Shark teeth are the most abundant vertebrate fossils, and shark vertebrae, which contain conspicuous growth increments, record an individual’s lifetime. Paleocological and modern ecological studies are increasingly using biogeochemical techniques such as stable isotope analysis, but key biological parameters are needed to accurately interpret isotopic data. For example, how much time is represented in a single tooth or vertebral growth band? Are there biological effects that alter the original ecological signals? This study analyzed the stable isotope composition of teeth and vertebrae from a long term feeding experiment with leopard sharks (Triakis semifasciata).

Shark teeth and vertebrae have two components that are useful for stable isotope analysis: the organic matrix and the inorganic tooth mineral. The organic portion of these calcified tissues includes carbon and nitrogen from diet. A comparison of isotope values for organic carbon and nitrogen from diet with carbon and nitrogen from teeth and vertebrae illustrates that there is a substantial offset due to biology. Interestingly, sharks have “conveyor belt-like” tooth replacement and the organic carbon isotope value varies among different tooth rows. This variation suggests that as shark teeth calcify before being upright and in use, there is continued organic carbon input/incorporation. These organic carbon and nitrogen isotope offsets will be important to interpret dietary and habitat preferences from modern shark teeth and vertebrae.

In addition to analyzing the organic carbon, we also analyzed the inorganic oxygen from the phosphate ion in the calcium phosphate mineral (hydroxyapatite) in shark teeth. The teeth used for this analysis were clipped from the front of the tooth row over the duration of the experiment (~3.5 years). The oxygen isotope values suggest there is no dietary effect, but mineralization of the teeth took approximately one year. This result is suprisingly long, and it indicates that seasonal migratory signals cannot be discerned from the stable isotope analysis of shark teeth.

This project was designed by Sora Kim while still a PhD student at the University of California, Santa Cruz, and she continued to work on the project while a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Wyoming. Beyond contributing to her professional development, the generation of these data provided undergraduate students at both universities valuable hand-on experience in conducting stable isotope analysis and data analysis. While a postdoctoral researcher, Sora Kim, honed her scientific and mentoring skills with these students. Finally, Sora Kim also helped develop and implement a one-week stable isotope ecology course for graduate students at Centro Interdisciplinario de Ciencias Marinas (CICIMAR) in La Paz, Mexico. This short course was co-taught by Drs. Marilyn Fogel, Seth Newsome, Brittany Graham, and Sora Kim and included students from six institutions in Mexico, Canada, and Argentina. Four students from this short course traveled to Wyoming to complete an internship with Drs. Newsome and Kim.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/15/2014
Modified by: Paul L Koch
